text:
So we've got a great guest
here in George Hoyem. He's the Vice President of
Investments at In-Q-Tel, a long time at In-Q-Tel.

Who hasn't heard of In-Q-Tel? OK, well, you have. OK, good. I'm going to tell you
a little bit about it.

You have, I'm going to
tell you about it anyways. But it's not for
profit VC firm that accelerates the development
and delivery of cutting

edge tech to the IC and USG. But In-Q-Tel is doing security
investing before it was cool.

I mean, it's all the rage now
with all the various defense tech and security tech
firms but they go way back.

They got famous companies
they got behind. Anyone heard of Palantir? More recently Anduril,
Github, Rocket Lab?

And a lot of them you
haven't heard of it because as soon as they
invest in a company, certain countries
start to take notice.

So they're behind even more
than you've even heard about. So why is this important? I mentioned this
a little bit when

we did some framing
remarks a couple of weeks back at the first meeting.

You know, the
technology that we're going to need to prevail in
this century's competition, it's not coming out
of government labs

or big primes or anywhere else. It's coming out of
the commercial sector. And we have to find ways to get
behind that technology early

and develop it and deploy
it at speed and scale. And that's exactly what In-Q-Tel
has done, with great success

and continues with
great success, thanks to George and to the other
members of his leadership team.

But George comes up, he's
got a lot of VC experience. He was most recently
the managing partner at Blueprint Ventures.

He was a General Manager of HPS,
our internet commerce division. We share something in common.

We were both junior high
school yearbook photographers. So that's a way to greatness. And he a great website.

What's it called again? Hoyem.com. Hoyem.com. There's a whole different
side of George if you log on and you'll see.

The soft side. But it catches on fire,
it's international. UK, Singapore-- you
told me somewhere else.

Sydney. Sydney, it's a
great, great company. And shameless plug
for all of you if you want to consider
going down that path,

you're here at the right place. But George, thanks for all
you're doing for all of us in this critical role. And thanks for joining
us here tonight.

Well, thanks for having me. Perfect. So, George, thanks again
for joining us here today.

Maybe we can kick off with-- so Joe gave a great introduction
of what is In-Q-Tel, but what is In-Q-Tel to you?

Like, how do you really
define the organization? Yeah, so first off we have
internships every summer.

So if anybody's interested in
that, hit us up afterwards. But In-Q-Tel, I think of it as
the it's the venture capital

arm of the US
intelligence community is the way to think about us. We were created by
the CIA 20 years ago.

And the mission
was pretty simple. It was to source innovation
from the startup community back in the dot
come era, and then

guide those technologies
into problems of national intelligence. And we do it in a
pretty novel way.

We have two kinds
of investments. We do equity only investments to
get involved with the company. But more importantly, we do
these adaptation projects where

we get a commitment from an end
user in one of the agencies we serve, and we make an investment
and guide those technologies

and adapt them appropriately
into pilots at scale. And so 75% of our deals are
piloted against real problems

and about half of
them are adopted, which is how we win by the
company and the customer conducting business directly.

And we support now-- we've
moved way beyond the CIA. We now support 11 intelligence
directorates, NSA, FBI, DHS,

DIA, cetera. I can explain all these acronyms
if anybody wants to know. So how did you join
In-Q-Tel and what

sparked the interest of
working at the intersection of technology and
national security? So I've been a tech
guy my whole career.

In fact, I was saying to Steve
Blank, we know each other-- I'm afraid to say how long
ago we met each other. But--

Steve taught me about
entrepreneurship when I was-- Well, he was the
original entrepreneur. Yeah. But I've been in the tech
business for a long time,

and I got into the
venture capital business because I was always a creator
of things inside big companies.

And I decided one
day after I helped sell to Hewlett Packard
this company called Verifone

who make the payment devices. And I'm hanging out at HP
and I thought, you know-- and I did a venture
capital backed

startup earlier in my career. I said, I want to become
a venture capitalist. And people said to me,
you don't know anything about venture capital. I said, well, I
raised money before.

And I was very dogged about it. And I convinced-- this is in
the run up to the dot com era-- and I convinced a company, a
venture capital firm to hire me

as a venture partner. Took a cut in pay
and dug in there and tried to transition into
the business, and here I am.

I backed a company from
my own venture firm that specialized in
corporate spin outs. That was our niche.

And we raised a couple of
hundred million dollars, and we were doing that. And there was a CEO of this
company called Sarvega. His name is Chris Darby.

And there was another
investor, his name was Steve Bauscher,
who became the number one and two at In-Q-Tel.

And a couple of years later,
Chris approached me and said, hey, why don't you give
back a little bit to us and come help us in the
valley, drive our brand.

And I'm more of an outward
focused part of the team, and the rest of them are kind
of a little more inward focused

at that time, and so they
convinced me to jump over. I have to admit, I didn't
know anything about the CIA.

It was kind of a scary thing. I was like CIA, I'm-- I'd done a deal with
In-Q-Tel before, but when I went back
to DC and understood

what they did, the
depth of reach that they had and the ability as an
individual to make an impact, I thought, wow,
that's pretty cool.

So I did that
almost 15 years ago and I never thought I
would be here this long. But everything, it's
just an interesting job

that it just kept me
here year after year. And I continue to
love what we do. So you lead the investment
team at In-Q-Tel.

You've been doing so for
the past several years. How does the investment
team sit within the In-Q-Tel organization?

Maybe can you share a
little bit more about that? How large is the investment
team, just a little bit more context. Sure.

So think of In-Q-Tel more like
a strategic investment firm. I think we're like maybe our
cousins or corporate venture

capital firms. So unlike financial
investors, we're driven-- we like to
make money, but we're driven by strategic intent,
not just making money.

But the most strategic
impact we have, by the way, are with the companies that we
make the most money, ironically, or maybe not so ironically.

So we're set up in-- we're much larger than the
average financial firm, meaning that the sort of
resources that we have.

So our model is to
actually do these deals, but more importantly, have a
programmatic function where

we actually-- to this earlier comment--
we actually adapt and drive these projects into pilots.

So when you think
about In-Q-Tel, we start off with the investment
team, and it's about 25 to 30

of us if you had our
international team. And so we're focused
more generally into these four areas
that I can explain later,

five areas actually. And then we get paired up with
a very deep technical bench. We have like 40
subject matter experts.

These are PhDs of
quantum computing or RF antennas or biotechnology. And so people like myself
are more generalists

and we have focus areas,
but we get paired up with a very deep bench
of technical experts. The technical experts are
crawling around our partners

in DC, so those are the
people that do deals. Our investment team hooks
up with our tech team

with the signal
from the customer, and we go out and do deals
and figure things out. Once we close a transaction,
we had a program management

function. So we have a program
management team that's probably 20, 25 people. And they do the programmatic
part of our mission.

And this is something
most VCs-- in fact, almost all VCs don't even have. Like, so we actually
manage these project,

we convene the customers. We're like a design
partner on steroids. And then we also have a
systems engineering team that's

probably 10 or 15 people. And these guys test
the deliverables because what do startups
products do when you give them

to companies? They blow up or they don't work. And so we actually
test these deliverables

to make sure that they meet
the contractual commitments and they actually work before we
hand them off to our customers to evaluate and run a pilot.

And then we have
lawyers and accountants and all the other
stuff you have. So if you had
In-Q-Tel up with all

these programmatic functions,
it's probably 180 people. But the investment team
is sort of those big--

it's the investment, program
management, the tech team, the systems engineering
team, and then what you call operations.

So you alluded to
these focus areas. Maybe can you dive more into
what are the focus areas? Yeah, so they
change a little bit

depending on the
canvas of investing. Right now we have a
cybersecurity practice, and we're super active.

And it's evolving into things
like deepfakes detection, for example, and synthetic
news and all that stuff.

Then we have a practice
we call it AI enablement. And so it used to be
called enterprise tech,

but now AI is the hottest
thing so everybody wants to put a generative AI
model on a classified network to get the bad guys
and figure stuff out.

And we can talk about that. But all the things related to an
enterprise or the AI enablement inside our partners is
a big, gigantic wave.

Then we have a group called
intelligent connectivity. And this is a lot of the James
Bond stuff, sensors, antennas,

power supplies, microphones,
spacetech, compute

high performance AI
semiconductors, for example. And then we have one
called advanced systems.

That's a little bit of
a different cut on that and could include
networking, quantum, and just more of the
technologies that are hard tech.

And then we also
have a biotechnology area and people are like, why
are you investing in biotech? Well, most of the
things we do originally

were around things
like, spy tech. Like, hey, I want to
get a piece of DNA

and have it last a long time
before I can take it somewhere and sequence it or
stuff like that.

But now it's moved into
things like synthetic biology and understanding
greater competition, what China is doing in this area.

And the sort of waves
that are happening in the synthetic biology
area are very transformative, and we're actively
investing in that area.

Yeah. And then you talked a
little bit about equity versus adaptation
sort of investments. Maybe you can share
a couple examples

of both equity versus adaptation
specifically within those focus areas.

Yeah, so we often start out
with an equity investment because we are fast by
government comparisons,

but we're not as fast as the
venture capital community. So-- Sometimes deals get
done in 48 hours here.

And we don't often
move that quick. But we're much faster than
government, thank god. So a lot of times we'll
be doing an investment

in an area and the government
is like, holy cow, I don't even know how to think about that. But we know where
it's going to trend,

and so we want to get
involved in the company early to put a spotlight on it. We also sometimes want to
get involved in something

because if something gets
really big and successful, we're a distraction. But if we get in
early, we can actually

have influence and help shape
the product for our partner base. So we're usually seed series A
and series B kinds of investors.

And it's important for
us to get involved early before we get one of these
adaptations pilots baked up,

because they're much
more complicated. They can also involve multiple
agencies at the same time. We have deals where we get two,
three, four, or five agencies

in the same transaction. So the equity only starts
there, and a huge percentage

of those in our North
America business will convert to one of
these adaptation projects.

So think of it as the farm team. And so that's kind of
the way we look at it. So of our equity only
investments, almost 60% of them

convert into these
adaptation projects that are potentially more impactful. And can you give us
a sense of numbers

here in terms of every year
how many equity, how many-- Yeah, so we're training at
about 75 investments a year

around our global canvas. Our international canvas is
10 to 15 deals outside the US.

In the United states,
probably 30 of them are these equity only
things and about 30 of them are these adaptation projects.

And over the years, we think
about that kind of accumulates. And we all-- the
unique distinction

of In-Q-Tel versus our friends
at down DIU, we go really early, we're very involved
in the company.

We take a board
seat in every deal we do because if you're
not in the board room, it's more like a
buy-sell relationship.

I mean, it's very
difficult to have understanding of what's broken,
what's working, what's not, and to actually
have the influence

to create a more
desirable outcome. Maybe we could talk about
investments like Anduril,

maybe we could talk about
that, or GitLab as well. Can you share a little bit more
about how that investment came

about and also what the
collaboration has been post-- Yeah, I think, Anduril-- how many of you have
heard of Anduril company?

OK. So Anduril, it was Trey
Stevens and Peter Thiel

are the founders. And they approached
us with an idea. They said, we want to
make a new age integrator. We think the system, the
integrators that are here today

are kind of old,
stodgy, not very quick. And we also want
to take advantage-- this is during the time when
the border wall was being built

and there was a lot of money
sloshing around Washington. And they said, we have
this idea of attacking this problem from
the border first,

but we don't know
where to start. And so we did a-- we
were in their seed round

and we walked them into their
first customs and border patrol. We took Anduril in, we pitched
them on the idea with Anduril,

and they came up with an
idea on how to help them with this border construction. And this was a very
lucky time for them

because there was
massive money being deployed to build the wall. And they took advantage
of that and they nailed

some gigantic early contracts. And now they've
expanded from there. And we've been a good
partner along the way.

We then followed that, we
did an early equity only deal and then we followed up
with, I think, two or three follow on adaptation projects.

And now they're being
used inside four or five of our agencies. So are we super
involved with them now?

No, because they've
graduated and they're very capable of doing
their own thing. But in the early days, if you
talk to anybody over there,

they'll say In-Q-Tel, A, they
delivered their first customer, and, B, was very impactful
to helping them understand the product market fit.

And what about
something like Gitlab? So GitLab is another
interesting-- how many of you know Gitlab?

So it was coming along
at the time, Github-- which was the sort of commercial
version of it was very popular.

It's a code repository
management CI/CD thing now, continuous integration,
continuous development

is what it stands for. So at the time they were
leveraging an open source version of Git.

And a lot of people thought,
well, why would you do that? Because GitHub was
dominating the market.

We saw an opportunity for an
on-prem version of GitHub or Git that would have the
sort of features

necessary for-- because
the government manages gigantic projects that are
software collaboration.

And they wouldn't work
with Github, which was like a web based thing. And it wasn't open
source, by the way.

So we engaged with them. They had never done business
with the government, but they had a really
killer open source product.

So I took the CEO of Gitlab,
I took him out to NSA. And I announced to
the NSA team, I said,

hey, we're bringing
the CEO GitLab in, and we want to do a
deal on this and that. So we walk into a
room, and about 10 guys

walk in with GitLab t-shirts. And we're like, I guess
you've heard of the company. And so they said, well,
what are you guys doing?

And he said, well, we've got
26,000 copies of GitLab running. And the company didn't
even know because they were

using the open source product. But there was all
this other stuff they were doing around
CICD, and we said, well,

what if we adapted the product,
built the right security features, helped you
get the things that you need to work in across the
whole premium product suite.

And they were doing zero
business with the government. So a couple of years-- well,
we did this adaptation project.

We gave them this one
feature, for example, to mirror data repositories
between the classified network

and what they call the
low network was just stuff like that. And so all of a sudden,
the fort was using it.

They tried-- we put
that premium product across the whole enterprise. And then fast forward
four years later, they

did eight figure
transaction deals and dominated and took
over the government

and really almost
wiped out GitHub. And we did that because we
walked them into the right place

and helped them
understand what to build. And they went public
shortly after that. We turned our little investment
there into like a lot of money.

So we talked about
GitLab as, really, a dual use company and then
also android, which is really

more defense government facing. Can you share your thoughts
in terms of, really--

I think we've
talked a lot about, in prior conversations,
dual use being perhaps more promising
than just defense facing,

but would love to-- Yeah, so there's-- those of us
who've been around a while-- Steve and Joe would know this--
like we see these multiple waves

and these bubbles form. And we're in one
of those bubbles in the defense tech
area, in my opinion, because there were some really
outsized returns with Anduril.

SpaceX is a good example of a
defense first company, Palantir, of course.

And so that's driven a lot of
venture capital into the sector. And there are some
defense first companies,

and there will be some. But the problem is there are
very few and far between. And the outsized
venture returns that you

would want to see from
those kinds of companies doesn't happen very
often, but there's a lot of money coming in.

So we continue to believe
that the primary focus and opportunity is dual use,
where you have a commercially successful company
like GitLab and you

find a dual use into
the federal government, but you draft and leverage
their commercial success

and make sure that
you don't make it so far off the reservation that
they have to constantly tweak it. And so I believe dual
use is here to stay.

We see with the Ukraine
conflict going on, the advent use of drones and
other technologies, wireless,

non-network comms, et
cetera, like huge movement to use commercial tech against
these military and defense use

cases. But I still believe the sweet
spot and the opportunity is more dual use
not defense first.

What are some characteristics
you see in successful dual use founders? You know, an openness.

Like there's this myth that
the Silicon Valley or the tech sector doesn't want to
work with the government.

And that's, in my
experience, there are some exceptions, like
consumer facing stuff, maybe. But the vast majority
of people who have--

they're trying to cross
the chasm, as we all know, and they're trying to get to
their first product market fit and customer.

And they have to have an
openness and willingness to think about
things creatively.

They have to be willing to
make an investment in something that's got a longer horizon. Even through In-Q-Tel, it'll
take a year or two or three

to nail it. So you've got to have a little
bit of a longer horizon, but we have lots of
examples of transactions

going from zero to seven
or eight figure partners. And the venture capital
community is paying attention.

So why can we get into
mostly every deal? Because they know
if it works, it can be an outsized
benefit to the company

much earlier than
they would find their way to the government. Most VCs will say, don't
bother with the government

until you're much, much larger. And I would say the same thing
as well without In-Q-Tel. I would say, don't
screw around with it.

It's just too hard to figure. You'll be dead by the
time you sell something to these characters. Yeah. What advice do you have for the
next generation of builders,

innovators, founders who
are interested in working at the intersection of
technology, innovation,

and national security? Work with In-Q-Tel. And I don't mean that
in a prerogative.

It is really hard to-- these are very opaque places. Now, the government writ
large, commercial like things

in the state and
local government and other civilian
agencies, easier to get to, but they don't
have as much money.

But the defense and
intelligence community has a lot of money, a
lot of hard problems. And if you can find
your way to those--

and there are firms now,
like Andreessen Horowitz has a really great defense
program, Lux Capital, Amplify.

There's some people
that have figured it out and they're very helpful, but
you've got to have a pathway in.

It's very difficult
to do on your own. You need a partner who
understands that market.

So I think this might be a good
time to bring up AJ over here. So AJ has been on the investment
team at In-Q-Tel for seven?

Seven years, yeah. Seven years? Yeah. Time is going fast. His hair was white when he
started, got white after he got

it. So AJ, maybe you could
share a little bit more about what's your day
to day like at In-Q-Tel.

Yeah, so I'm AJ Burton. And I'm a Managing Partner. I work for George. He was talking about
how our team is set up

two different coasts
for our investment team. We have a small office just
up the street in Menlo Park, and that's the team that I lead.

In terms of day to day,
no two days are the same. I spend a lot of time in
board meetings these days.

I spend a lot of
time with pipeline. I also spend a lot of time
with our government partners. As I have come up the
ranks, I spend more time

with the East Coast
of our organization. And a lot of time
developing your people. That too, yeah.

So, yeah, never a dull day. I would say, honestly,
majority of my time now is with portfolio companies
and with the internal team,

doing a little bit less
on the new deal front. But, yeah, hopefully that
gives you a little bit of a flavor for it.

And I think you're also working
on the DIU collaboration. And George, of course, alluded
to DIU Defense Innovation

Unit down the street
in Moffett Field. Can you share more about how
In-Q-Tel is differentiated

within the innovation ecosystem
from other partners like DIU? Yeah. So in a prior life I
served on active duty

in the army for seven years. And I think when I showed up
to In-Q-Tel people were like, army guy understands DOD, so why
don't you go off and figure out

this DIUX thing at the time? He understood more of
the acronyms than I did. That's true, yeah. And, yeah, I have kind
of been our point person

for DIU for the last
several years at this point. Steve Boucher, our
CEO, and Doug Beck,

the current Director
of DIU, were just actually on stage at CFR
a couple of weeks ago and articulated, I think,
a framing between the two

organizations that really
works well where In-Q-Tel is the early stage. George talked a
little bit about this, kind of identifying these
really, really early stage

opportunities that have
potential and helping shepherd them and potentially
adapt their product

to what I call product
mission fit, essentially, some validation that this
commercial product is

useful against mission. And then if you liken this
to a venture capital analogy, you have a later stage investor
or a growth stage investor,

which is DIU coming in
to essentially scale that technology for what they
call defense market penetration.

So In-Q-Tel early stage,
DIU growth stage, we're doing the early
identification adaptation,

find product mission
fit, and then DIU comes in to really scale it. Maybe question for both of you.

Best or favorite deal
that you've worked on. How much time do we have?

That would be for a bad
deal or something like that. You have never done a bad deal. No, that's not true. I would say it takes $20 million
to train a venture capitalist.

I don't know if I've
spent that much yet. Best deal, unfortunately, this
is one that's not announced.

So one challenging thing about
In-Q-Tel is probably only 10% of the investments we make,
maybe a little bit more now,

15%-- what do you think, George? Something like that. Let's say 10% to 15%
of the investments we make are publicly disclosed.

It's not like it's
secret or classified, but for reasons that relate
to confidentiality for both our government partners and
our portfolio companies,

we typically don't make
the relationship public. In this case, the
example, I think my biggest winner is one that
we have not publicly disclosed.

It is a Stanford
affiliated company for co-founders from
Stanford, and it's

been an amazing journey. One of my first
investments back in 2018, we started off very small with
one government relationship.

That one relationship
grew to five relationships within the confines of
the In-Q-Tel relationship.

And then the company started
to go out on its own. It started to build
out its federal team. We were a part of that hiring.

They started to secure
contracts, seven figure, eight figure contracts. And now I'm still
hanging around the hoop

on the board as an observer,
but the company, by and large, is really on its own. It's blossomed into a very, very
large public sector business.

It's been extremely fulfilling,
and most importantly, it's been very impactful
to government. Sorry I can't share the name.

It's always tough
when you can't share and then it means you just-- Hopefully I gave enough info-- --either since you
don't share that data.

That's OK. George, do you have
a best or favorite? Well, I think the GitLab is
one of my public examples.

I have another one like AJ
that it's not announcement. Came out of University
of Michigan, and it's-- we were really involved very
early to help shape the product,

and they're just
crushing it right now. These things will become
more visible later. On the what is your
worst deal site,

most of the times
when it doesn't work is when you have founders--
well, it's all about the product

market fit. And you have to be open to the
journey of pivoting and finding your way, but founders who
don't listen to the marketplace

are usually the most acute
failures because they think they know the answer, they
know what the customers really want. But in the end of the day,
we have to follow the money

and follow the customer
demand, so lots of examples of companies
that didn't make it because of arrogance of the founder
or a lack of willingness

to listen to the market signals. And occasionally you just
whiff because one of my most

spectacular failures--
this is not at In-Q-Tel-- but I invested in a
company that was-- this is back in the days
of internet peering.

Steve may remember these
days, but like bandwidth was really expensive. And it was like, wow, if we
can make this less expensive,

we'll make a lot of money. And we went and we invested in
this company that could really

reduce the cost of
bearing bandwidth, like, accessing internet works. And the prices collapsed
right after we did the deal.

The thing went to zero. Which reminds me of like today,
large language models and Gen AI

are using massive amounts
of compute resources. And I guarantee
you, someone's going to figure out how to do that
for an order of magnitude, less

money. And the people that are
betting for the cost of compute there to be the same are going
to get crushed, probably.

But that's the kind of thing
that you can get caught on to these market trends that are
really macro trends that you

can't fight. And sometimes your
worst deals will happen in those macro trends. AJ, do you have
a worse deal or--

No, I have a couple
that have gone to zero. It is a risk business
at the end of the day.

I mean, the government funds
us to specifically find early stage companies
knowing that they're risky.

So we're not looking
for 100% success. If we were to have that, we'd
not be taking enough risk. We really are trying to go
for the outsized outcomes,

so it's OK that there
have been some failures. I would add to George's
comment, if you're talking about why things
fail on the founders side,

we also sometimes
experience challenges on the government side. Champions and government
often get promoted and go on

to the next position,
and now the person who potentially
endorsed the adaptation or had a use case for the
technology is no longer there.

So that can be very hard. We de-risk that by trying to
bring more than one government agency to the table.

George mentioned we're working
with 11 or something like that. It changes a little
bit every year. We're trying to build
redundancy and where can

we find commonality of the use
case across our intelligence community partners so
that if one were to leave

or if someone's going
to get promoted, there's still opportunity
there for the company. It also allows the government to
get leverage out of its dollars.

We can do more with
dollars from each partner, so that's another
area where I've seen failures on the government
side, turnover of personnel.

Why don't we open
up for questions. Questions from-- yes.

What's the difference between
you guys and a phase two SBIR?

George, you want to take that? Go ahead. Yeah. Well, a phase two SBIR, as
you know, is grant funding.

It's non-dilutive funding. And I'm assuming you're
kind of framing it within that AFWERX program?

And SBIR is a small business
administration grant that you could
technically get from a lot of different entities,
but most people

refer to it within the
construct of the AFWERX program. What I would say is when the
SBIR program was initially

created, the idea
was not to facilitate what we call solution transfer,
essentially bringing product

to mission. It was more about
increasing the air force's, what they call the CTIB,
the commercial technology

industrial base. Essentially the number
of commercial entities that are doing business
with the air force,

lowering the bar for them to
do business with the air force, basically bringing
them in the front door. And because that was
the initial vision,

I think what we've
seen over time is that their solution transfer
rates have been very, very low because it's
not really oriented

around adapting technology
for some mission application. So what is the
biggest difference?

I would say ultimately
it relates to, is your technology going
to be useful to mission? Now, granted, the SBIR
program has been successful

in terms of that CTIB
objective, but it hasn't really transitioned many
programs from phase two

to phase three, which is some
direct contract that's not under the SBIR umbrella or
some larger program of record

or something like that. Of course, there are exceptions,
but that's my two cents and has been my impression after
tracking this for the last five

years or so. Why does CIA chose the VC model
instead of just giving a grant?

So the thing that we do,
like you can see it with DIU, in their early days, if
you're not in the boardroom--

and how do you buy your
way into the boardroom? You buy it in through equity. And if you're not in
the boardroom-- again,

back to this buy-sell
relationship-- you don't have the insights
to help shape things, to understand where things
are going to go wrong,

to be a strategic
partner at the table. And so the IFTA
model is really-- without being in the boardroom,
it really wouldn't work.

In fact, we get in the
boardrooms of companies for a really tiny
amount of money relative to our
peer group, and it's

because it's a price of entry. You want our help, we want
to be a strategic partner. We're not interested in
the buy-sell relationship.

And so CIA does
lots of stuff where they have cyber equivalents
and they have Kratos

and they have research
grants, but they don't really have the control over the model
or the efficacy that we do.

And for the amount of money
we spend, the efficacy that we get-- like we spend a
tiny fraction of what DIU does,

for example, and we
have, we would argue, very high impact potential. And it's unique.

I don't think In-Q-Tel
could get created today. It was created in a time of
certain bipartisan creation.

We actually were created under a
thing called title eight, which is a unique exception
with the authorities

to do what we do to hold
equity and sit in a boardroom. It's a very unique capability. No one else in the government
has found their way

to the authorities
to do what we do yet. Even around the world, I
think, we're pretty unique.

And I'd love to hear
thoughts from either of you on counterintelligence
in Silicon Valley.

In particular, it's
no secret that there's US competitors that spend
a lot of funds and effort

trying to collect
national security secrets from early stage
technology companies. How are you considering that
challenge with your portfolio

or your greater
relationships in government? Well, let me start
by saying that there

are certain of our adversaries
or our competition partners around the world.

I think the Chinese,
everybody knows, would-- acquiring intellectual
property in a company

is just another
form of competition. And I have tried to back-- well, I've backed a
dozen companies that

tried to enter the
Chinese market, and every single one of
them eventually pulled out because they stuffed-- their
stuff was reverse engineered

or they were marginalized
out of the business. And so it's something
you have to be aware of. If you're a company,
you want to do business

in certain parts of the world,
your IP is going to be attacked and going to be repurposed.

And it's just it's just
another form of competition, so you have to be aware of it. So we spent a lot of time
coaching our companies

on what they should
expect, what they could do, and how to protect their
IP and their markets

and their intellectual property. It's just a reality of the
way the world is right now.

Yeah, I think that's good. And I mentioned before,
we don't disclose a lot of our investments. One of the reasons
is because we don't

want to make them targets for
a foreign intelligence service. This topic of FOCI, foreign
ownership control and influence,

is one that that acronym now
is here in Silicon Valley. Some people know what that is.

It's becoming a
part of the lexicon and people are
talking about it more. We get questions
from entrepreneurs around, hey, if I take
this foreign capital, what

are the impacts,
potentially, to me? And we don't have-- there's no black and white rule
and nor are we an authority

but back to our board
observer positions, we can help advise companies
and other board directors

on the potential second
and third order effects of those things. So it's definitely a topic
that's in focus right now.

And you're seeing
some venture funds as well, very high
prominent tier one investors that are forking off
their Chinese subsidiaries

or other parting ways with
foreign entities because of this exactly. So it'll be interesting
to see how it trends--

Like, we don't put any
terms in any of our deals, like, no, you can't
do this or that. Like, we want to-- the fear and greed of
capitalism is a great motivator

for the right thing to do. And so people make
their choices, we tell them what
the implications are
and we don't get in the way. There was another question.

Do you think there's
an opportunity for a setup like In-Q-Tel
for non-defense investments
in the government? Yeah, in fact, we helped spawn-- there's this barda--

GHIC, Global Health
Investment Corporation. Yeah, Global Health
Investment Corp. It's a biotech related fund.

We coached and gave
them the playbook and helped them get that going.

And that's a good use
in the biotech area. It's underneath the HHS, I
think, if I'm not mistaken.

The UK created this
thing called NCIS, NCIS. NCIF. NCIF, thank you, NCIF.

And we totally coached them
up, handed them a playbook, showed them how to do it.

And they have their own
In-Q-Tel style thing in the UK that they're doing now, which
is a testament to the model.

So, yeah, I think there's
a lot of opportunity that comes back to the authorities,
like where in the government,

and particularly in a
divided congress and the sort of political environment
right now, where do you get the authorities
to create something

that can do what we do? And we were created at a time 25
years ago when there was less-- well, first of
all, people didn't

understand what equity was, but
there was less partisan views on this stuff.

Yes. Right. I'm from Ukraine, and I

are looking out for funding. So I'm curious, what's your

in defense space,
specifically in Ukraine, if you have any

here in the US. What are some of

technologies and startups that

established outside of the US? Yeah, we have not
invested in Ukraine. Yet.

We have presence in Europe. I think we're
spending time there, but we have not made
an investment yet.

In terms of advice for
selling to the US government, I think the first
thing, depending on what you're developing, you
need to familiarize yourself

with the various
export control regimes, most likely something
called ITAR.

That's potentially if you
don't have the right licenses for selling and
exporting technology, you could very quickly
get hemmed up there.

we often don't do
defense first deals like things that are
kinetic, guns, missiles.

That's just not
our space, frankly. That's the land of systems
integrators and defense contractors.

And they're very
nichey things that often are cost plus
kinds of models that don't fit the venture regime.

So if there's something
a venture capitalist with co-invest with
us, that would be, but most of these defense
types of technologies

are really not what we do. And we've done some drone stuff. We did Skydio, for example,
which is now scaling.

I would think that the
NSSIF or NSSIF, NSSIF is what it is, that that might
be more relevant or also Diana

or the NIF, the NATO Innovation
Fund or investment fund. There are some things
that are popping up

or that have popped up in
the last couple of years that are more closely, I
think, are in your back door.

By the way, we have 30 of
our portfolio companies actively being used in
deployed in Ukraine right now.
So we're helping from that side. Go ahead.

Nothing else on the theme
of the previous question is a nonprofit that's investing
public money in confidentially.

I'm curious about what are
the sort of metrics of success you can define and
track how these might be different from other VC firms
and ultimately sort of what

include people accountable. On the first, like any
strategic investor,

including corporate
VCS, by the way, they have the same challenge. We are very acute in measuring
both quantitative and

qualitative criteria. Our KPIs, our most
important KPIs pilots

against real problems
and adoptions, and then we measure
mission impact.

And so those are a little bit
of quantitative and qualitative. We do like to make
money, and so we

track our return on investment. Amazingly, our returns
in our venture investing

are top quartile,
maybe top decile. It's amazing because
we get signal from the partners we work
with and we help them succeed.

So we measure success-- basically pilots and adoptions
are highest order, and then

mission impact. Yeah, and adoption,
I typically describe to an entrepreneur as portfolio
company technology making

a positive impact on the
national security community's mission. And as a result of that, the
national security community making a positive impact on
the company's income statement.

That is-- and George
references before-- that is what keeps the
flywheel spinning, both sides of the equation
getting value from it.

The other thing quickly to
add is proceeds come back to our balance sheet,
but we plow them back into the business for
incremental tax payer benefit.

So we're recycling dollars. All the equity
investments we make are from our balance
sheet, essentially proceeds

from past investments. We're reducing the cost
to the taxpayer over time. We made a decision early on--

originally we had a
small venture fund that was venture
economics, but we determined that that
caused a lack of alignment

between us and our partners,
because if someone at In-Q-Tel is getting rich on the
backs of the taxpayers, that wouldn't be cool.

So we pay our people
very well but we decided not to move to an
incentive structure like Kerry. And so people that
work at In-Q-Tel

have to be into the mission. We pay very well. We pay corporate venture
kinds of compensation,

but you'll never get
rich at In-Q-Tel. And it's important
for us to keep that construct so that we
can have the right alignment
with our partners.

I think about a year ago
we had the Department of Defense, Office of
Strategic Capital Income.

And I guess I'm
just curious how you see In-Q-Tel is doing
something different or as

how you're distinct from
other intra government VCs and also whether you foresee
a future in which there's

sort of a diverse
environment of competing inter-government
venture capitalists. Is that something
you think would be--

Eric here from OSCE, why don't
you grab a mic and come up? I will take a shot of that.

You bet. And to clear on that, I
no longer work for OSCE.

I'm not part of the
government, but I was part of the team that stood that up. And one of the key
differences, essentially,

is the type of financial
tool that's used. What we're talking about
here are equity investments,

sometimes contracts, but the
Office of Strategic Capital relies primarily on
debt-based tools,

like loans and loan guarantees. So you can imagine that a lot
of component level technologies in particular need large
amounts of debt-based financing

for scaled production. You could think of creating
facilities or anything that needs patient capital
over the long term,

and that would be a key
difference essentially in the financial instruments. Yeah, I think that's right. At the end of the
day, it's great

that the government
is doing everything it can to drive capital into
areas that technology areas

that matter for
national security. So In-Q-Tel actually has a
small partnership with OSCE now. It's very complementary
to our model.

And to your bigger
picture point, again, it's great
that the government is trying to pull out
all stops to drive money

where it matters the most. In-Q-Tel is just one
part of it, right. There's no possible way our
model could address it all.

And it's great that
the government's innovating with things like OSCE
and boosting DIUs budget as well

on the procurement side. So really pulling
out all the stops. So maybe final question.

Now with this current
great power competition, what is In-Q-Tel
thinking about actively, especially as we've moved on
from a global war on terror?

So one of the
interesting things that happened to us a couple
of years ago, so we're moving towards potentially
decoupling our economies,

the East and the West. And we've seen all the
supply chain challenges. And part of it is
that the East will not

play on the same competitive
rules as the West. Like you can't own
controlling interest in companies for the most
part, stuff like that.

So we saw this
happening years ago and we're seeing
competition move

from kinetic forms
of competition to intellectual property and
supply chain and technology

and economics. And so what happened is the
CIA actually reorganized a bunch of their assets
inside their agency

and created a thing
called T2MC which-- Stands for Technology and
Transnational Mission Center.

There you go. AJ is really good at that. Yeah, he's got the acronym MIND. But technology becomes--
because mission centers,

they have mission centers that
are set up for problem areas, like how are you going to go
organize around a problem. And so they created
one around technology.

And they're saying
like, technology is now the new battleground. And so they looked
around and they said,

we've got this
asset, In-Q-Tel, that has a global
footprint and probably the deepest view of
technology trends of anybody

in the government. And now they're looking to
us to help them understand what's going on with quantum
computing, what's happening

with semiconductor supply
chains, what's happening with new wireless technologies,
non-terrestrial networks, space

tech. And so they come to us and we
can help give them guidance on how these things are
breaking and where's--

what papers are being
published, where's the center of gravity
around these things and how do we factor that
into our national security

and defense strategies. And so we're more of a
voice on both Capitol Hill

and in the
intelligence community to help inform policymakers of
how these trends are breaking and how they should think
about it from a technology

perspective. George, AJ, thank you both
for joining us here today. Of course. Thanks for having us.

You know what's going
